summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 between attorney Stacey Richman and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS). The emails discuss threats and extortion attempts against Mark Epstein, the brother of Jeffrey Epstein, following Jeffrey's death. Richman requests FBI assistance and coordination regarding these threats.

persons.name: Stacey Richman
persons.context: Attorney representing Mark Epstein, corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding threats and extortion attempts against her client. She mentions arranging personal security for Mark after Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Brother of Jeffrey Epstein who is receiving death threats and extortion demands for bitcoin in exchange for information. His attorney states he had previously been contacted by the FBI (SA Ponder) and that he perceived the agent was not concerned.

persons.name: SA Ponder
persons.context: FBI Special Agent who spoke with Mark Epstein the week prior to this email chain about threats. The U.S. Attorney's Office indicates they will ask SA Ponder to reach out to Mark again.

connections.description: Stacey Richman is the attorney representing Mark Epstein, handling threats and coordinating with law enforcement on his behalf.
SA Ponder, an FBI agent, spoke with Mark Epstein about threats he was receiving. Mark reportedly did not perceive the agent as concerned.

events.title: Aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's Death
events.description: Reference to 'initial threats immediately after his brother's death' for which Stacey Richman arranged personal security for Mark Epstein.

keyFacts: Mark Epstein, Jeffrey Epstein's brother, was receiving death threats and extortion demands for bitcoin in exchange for information in May 2020.
Attorney Stacey Richman had previously arranged personal security for Mark Epstein following the initial threats after Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019.
FBI Special Agent SA Ponder had spoken with Mark Epstein about these threats the week prior to the May 25, 2020 email.
Mark Epstein reportedly perceived that SA Ponder was not concerned or interested in the threats during their prior contact.
The email chain indicates an ongoing concern about 'random contacts and approaches' and potential extortionists targeting Mark Epstein.
